text: The POU transcription factors <extra_id_0> Oct-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Oct-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> regulate the activity of octamer - dependent promoters , including those that direct transcription from rearranged immunoglobulin genes .

Unlike <extra_id_0> Oct-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which is constitutively expressed in many cell types , <extra_id_0> Oct-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression is restricted primarily to B lymphocytes and can be induced in precursor B cells by stimulation with bacterial lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) .

text: However , the precise factors that mediate this induction mechanism remain unknown .

In the present study , we monitored <extra_id_0> Oct-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in cells arrested for the activation of NF-kappaB , an LPS - responsive member of the Rel transcription factor family .

Despite stimulation with LPS , disruption of the NF-kappaB signaling pathway in precursor B cells led to the loss of inducible <extra_id_0> Oct-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> DNA binding activity in vitro and the suppression of <extra_id_0> Oct-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - directed transcription in vivo .

text: The finding that <extra_id_0> Oct-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is under NF-kappaB control highlights an important cross-talk mechanism involving two distinct transcription factor families that regulate B lymphocyte function .
